p.bold: 1. Bilateral endogenous Serratia marcescens endophthalmitis secondary to endocarditis following cardiac surgery
DAM Lyall, ME Gregory, J McDonnell, F De Villiers and D Tejwani

sec.p: An acutely insightful account of systemic infection with devastating ocular destruction is pictured by digital photography and orbital computerised tomography. The detailed content is well structured combining key elements of investigation, differential diagnosis and management with learning outcomes and a comprehensive literature review.

p.bold: 2. Spontaneous remission in a case of idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis
G Williams, B Sarkar, JB Neilly and GA McKay

sec.p: Also known as Ormond's disease, an exaggerated inflammatory response affecting the retroperitoneum is demonstrated using computed tomography (CT) to identify surgical complications. Content includes immunopathology and 9 references.

p.bold: 3. Two rare cases of retinal vasculitis following vaccination

sec.p: With the increasing use of seasonal influenza vaccines, authors stress the importance of recognising retinal vasculitis-a rare autoimmune adverse reaction of vaccination. Colour fundus photograpy and fluorescein angiography images are provided.

p.bold: 4. A young healthy male with syncope and complete heart block
V Chauhan, N Chauhan, CGS Chauhan and M Vaid

sec.p: Clinicians in Philadelphia analyse cardiac syncope secondary to fluctuating heart block in a previously healthy male of US origin. Authors warn of the re-emergence of vector-borne diseases, such as Borrelia burgdorferi as a result of climate change. With 21 references, this case report ‘ticks’ all the right boxes.

p.bold: 5. A case of sebaceous carcinoma arising in a benign cystic teratoma of the ovary and review of the literature
Y Moghaddam, R Lindsay, J Tolhurst, D Millan and N Siddiqui

sec.p: The clinico-pathological and immunological features of this the eighth reported case of a moderately differentiated sebaceous carcinoma arising in a dermoid cyst of the ovary are elaborately described. The literature review comprises a lavish 45 references.

p.bold: 6. An unusual cause of acute internal haemorrhage: cystic artery pseudoaneurysm secondary to acute cholecystitis
AKY Fung, A Vosough, S Olson, EH Aly and NR Binnie

sec.p: A clinical review of this patient’s management concludes that, while spontaneous cystic artery haemorrhage is a rare complication of acute cholecystitis, a high index of clinical suspicion is required to diagnose this life-threatening condition. Aids to diagnosis and therapeutic options are discussed.

p.bold: 7. Acute distal radial epiphyseal osteomyelitis: a case report

sec.p: While in the case of these paediatric orthopaedics surgeons, the exact cause of the epiphyseal haematogenous osteomyelitis could not be determined, it is likely it was precipitated by trauma. MRI played a vital role in providing a definitive diagnosis. Some will jump at the chance to challenge the comparison to the ‘rabbit tibial trauma model’.
